image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from Virginia; born in Danville, Pittsylvania County, Va., January 25, 1836; attended the Danville Academy, and the law school of the University of Virginia at Charlottesville in 1857; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Danville in 1858; edited the Republican and later the Democratic Appeal in Danville; elected Commonwealth attorney for Danville in September 1858, and served until April 23, 1861, when he volunteered as a private in the Confederate Army; commissioned major in June 1861 and was assigned to the Eighteenth Regiment, Virginia Infantry; promoted to the rank of colonel and served until the close of the Civil War; resumed the practice of his profession; elected as a Democrat to the Forty-fourth and to the five succeeding Congresses (March 4, 1875-March 3, 1887); chairman, Committee on Railways and Canals (Forty-fifth and Forty-sixth Congresses); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1886 to the Fiftieth Congress; resumed the practice of law in Danville, Va.; died in Baltimore, Md., June 23, 1906; interment in Green Hill Cemetery, Danville, Va.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Cabell, George C. The answer of George C. Cabell to the notice of contest of Jno. T. Stovall, fifth Virginia district. Washington, D.C.: R.O. Polkinhorn, printer, 1881.
------. Tariff and internal taxation. [Washington: R. O. Polkinhorn, printer, 1878].

Goode, John. In the contested election case of John T. Stovall, contestant vs. George C. Cabell, contestee. From the Fifth Congressional District of Virginia. Brief on behalf of contestee. Washington: R. O. Polkinhorn, 1882.

researchRecord.name: In the Cabell Family Papers, 1778-1893, approximately 100 pages.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include George Craighead Cabell. An unpublished finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Virginia Politicians' and Authors' Papers, 1874-1883, 8 pages.
researchRecord.description: Includes letters sent by George Craighead Cabell to Benjamin Perley Poore regarding changes of address. Also includes correspondence from George Cabel to John K. Martin, in which John Martin apologizes for an offensive letter. An inventory is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the James Taylor Ellyson Papers, ca. 1865-1910, approximately 1,500 items.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include George C. Cabell. A finding aid is available in the repository and online.

recordLocation.name: The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library
